Â© 2015 Aaron Haines This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. ## Go! ![robo](file:///E:/aaron/Documents/My%20Documents/COMPSCI%20101/Images/robo.png "Robo") Here is Robo, maybe we will build him one day. ![Inside Robo](file:///E:/aaron/Documents/My%20Documents/COMPSCI%20101/Images/head.png "Inside Robo") He has a central processing unit somewhere inside his head that reads computer programs and runs them, and some flash memory where all of the computer programs are stored. > Go check his hardware by pressing the button
Checking hardware... CPU installed Flash Memory installed Everything is OK! > A central processing unit has something to do with (tick a box): - [ ] running programs - [ ] storing programs - [ ] eating programs > Flash memory has something to do with: - [ ] running programs - [ ] watching programs - [ ] storing programs ![Go Robo](file:///E:/aaron/Documents/My%20Documents/COMPSCI%20101/Images/go_robo.png "Go Robo, move!") He doesn't understand the language we speak, he only understands Robo Language 1.0, which is installed in the flash memory. Robo Language 1.0 looks like this: ![robo-lang1](file:///E:/aaron/Documents/My%20Documents/COMPSCI%20101/Images/robo-lang1.png "Robo Language 1.0") Let's program Robo to move somewhere.
![course](file:///E:/aaron/Documents/My%20Documents/COMPSCI%20101/Images/course.png "Obstacle Course") > Go write a move.bot program, upload it to Robo and then run it. // Anything after two slashes is a comment that tells us stuff // Comments are not part of the program // Write move.bot below //
Uploading program move.bot to Flash Memory
Reading program move.bot from Flash Memory Running program move.bot Usually programs are typed on computers with keyboards and usually programming languages are made up of those keyboard characters. Let's update our software to Robo Language 2.0 using the terminal. > Go write `update robo-lang` after the `$` $ Updating robo-lang to version 2.0 Update complete! Robo Language 2.0 looks like this: step 2 // step forward two spaces, you can choose any number turn right // turn right 90 degrees, you can choose left also Let's program Robo to get back to the start. > Go write a program, `upload move.bot` and then `run move.bot` // Write move.bot here //
$ Uploading program move.bot to Flash Memory $ Reading program move.bot from Flash Memory Running program move.bot Let's get ready for the next course. ![crack](file:///E:/aaron/Documents/My%20Documents/COMPSCI%20101/Images/crack.png "Crack in Course") A big crack has appeared in Robo's path! But we do not have an instruction that can get him over it. In programming you can write new programs to do things. What we need is more control over Robo. > Go `update robo-lang` $ Updating robo-lang to version 3.0 Update complete! Robo Language 3.0 looks like this: // Importing Robo Language 3.0 function which jumps Robo over one space import legs.jump jump() : // New jump function legs.jump() jump() // Using jump function step(2) turn(90) > Go write a program, upload and then run it. // Write move.bot here //
$ Uploading program move.bot to Flash Memory $ Reading program move.bot from Flash Memory Running program move.bot Robo was taking awhile to process our new instructions. It is time we upgraded his hardware. ![Inside Robo](file:///E:/aaron/Documents/My%20Documents/COMPSCI%20101/Images/head.png "Inside Robo") Inside Robo's head is the CPU that reads and runs our program and the flash memory where we are storing our program. As a program gets bigger more and more instructions are being read from our program. We are using flash memory to store our program but this can be slow to read from. A type of fast memory is called RAM. RAM is fast to read and write to but when the power goes off everything is erased. We will store our program in flash memory, when we run our program the CPU will copy the program from flash memory to RAM, and then the CPU will read our instructions faster from RAM. Let's install some RAM. > Go write RAM in the empty part ![RAM](file:///E:/aaron/Documents/My%20Documents/COMPSCI%20101/Images/ram.png "Install RAM") > Go `check hardware` $ Checking hardware... CPU installed Flash Memory installed RAM installed Everything is OK! > Go run the program again. $ Copying program move.bot from Flash Memory to RAM Reading program move.bot from RAM Running program move.bot We are ready to begin COMPSCI 101 and learn to... ![hacker](file:///E:/aaron/Documents/My%20Documents/COMPSCI%20101/Images/hacker.png "Hacker") Wait a minute somebody is hacking into Robo! To stop somebody else programming Robo we need security. > Go `set password` $ Enter Password: Confirm Password: Password Set! ![hacker_no](file:///E:/aaron/Documents/My%20Documents/COMPSCI%20101/Images/hacker_no.png "Hacker Stopped") Take that hacker! Good, now we have had a taste of what this course is all about. Let's move on.
